title: Warning: Vaccination Death & Bioweapon Conspiracy Theory Could Amplify Panic

Unable to disproof

The sudden deaths after vaccination was one of the hot topics of last week. According to IORGâ€™s database, there are 3,555 related Facebook posts from Mandarin pages between June 14th and 20th. Although Taiwanâ€™s Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) said the causality between death and vaccination needs to be verified, the decrease in the number of people getting vaccinated already reflects the publicâ€™s hesitation.

â€œVaccines are a biochemical weapon,â€ a conspiracy theory that appeared last week might deepen peopleâ€™s concern on vaccines. Since June 12th, messages containing words like â€œthe inventor of mRNA vaccine platform Dr. Robert Malone regrets getting vaccinated with Modernaâ€ started to appear. Similar content also showed up on PTT and United Daily News. Soon after, narratives such as â€œThe U.S. Supreme Court has canceled universal vaccinationâ€ and â€œVaccines are a biochemical and genocidal weaponâ€ started to emerge, warning people not to get vaccinated. In 2020, IORGâ€™s research report included a conspiracy theory saying that COVID-19 virus is a biochemical weapon fabricated by the U.S. Both conspiracy theories used sources that are unverifiable, which can be considered as â€œsource manipulation.â€ It should be noted that IORG has not yet found any direct CCP involvement in the dissemination of this narrative.

Another hot topic last week was â€œAmerica donates 2.5 million doses of Moderna to Taiwan.â€ Between June 19th and 20th, the dates when the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced the news on its Facebook page and the arrival of the vaccines, there were at least 899 related Facebook posts from Mandarin pages. Besides showing appreciation towards the U.S., narratives saying that â€œTaiwan uses arm purchase and semiconductor chips in exchange for American vaccinesâ€ were also observed, implying that the U.S. is driven by self-interest and ill-intentioned. Chinese state media Global Times has published at least 3 articles echoing the same narratives, writing that â€œthere is no free lunchâ€ and that â€œthe U.S. is only using Taiwan as its pawn to confront the mainland.â€ The involvement of Chinese state media shows that the CCP intends to amplify these narratives, for internal propaganda, stability maintenance, or undermining Taiwan-U.S. relations.

2 suspicious narratives mentioned in last weekâ€™s Weekly: â€œU.S. company Blackwater invested in the R&D of Taiwanese vaccine UB-612â€ and â€œTaiwanese going to China to get vaccinatedâ€ continued to spread. IORG found more pro-China celebrities and local collaborators who participated in spreading these narratives. In an interview video with Wang Ping-chung (ç‹ç‚³å¿ ) published on Xigua Video (è¥¿ç“œè¦–é »), a Chinese online video-sharing platform owned by ByteDance, former Taiwan legislator Chiu Yi (é‚±æ¯…) claimed that â€œBlackwater offers personal protections to President Tsai Ing-wenâ€, and that Tsai wants to â€œuse force to reject reunificationâ€ (ä»¥æ­¦æ‹’çµ±) and to â€œuse force to plot for independenceâ€ (ä»¥æ­¦è¬€ç¨). Huang Chih-hsien (é»ƒæ™ºè³¢), a Taiwanese TV commentator, wrote in a Facebook post that America uses Blackwater to conduct â€œhuman experimentâ€ in Taiwan in order to â€œproduce biochemical weapon that targets the Chineseâ€. Another TV commentator Sisy Chen (é™³æ–‡èŒœ) also said in her TV program that â€œThe founder of Blackwater has registered a new company in Hong Kongâ€ to â€œassist the PLA to train African special forces.â€ When combined with the emotional calling of â€œTaiwanese going to China to get vaccinated,â€ these suspicious narratives could change the perception and preference of vaccines among the Taiwanese public.

The famous content farm Mission (å¯†è¨Š) and its Chinese connection was revealed by The Reporter in 2019. Sharing of links from the content farm was banned by Facebook in the same year. However, Mission resurrected itself with a new domain â€œpplomo.comâ€ and is alive and well. According to IORGâ€™s database, between June 14th and 20th, there are 660 Facebook pages conducted â€œclustered postingâ€, and the domain most-shared among these clustered posts is the one of Mission, with a total of 101 links being shared in a short period of time. The Facebook pages that share Missionâ€™s links the most frequently are: â€œSuperwoman blue warriorâ€ (ç¥åŠ›å¥³è¶…äººè—æˆ°å°‡), â€œBlue sky R.O.C. once moreâ€ (è—å¤©å†ç¾ä¸­è¯æ°‘åœ‹), â€œChinese chatâ€ (è¯äººèŠå¤©), â€œEmpty Tsai Governmentâ€ (ç©ºå¿ƒèœæ”¿åºœ), and â€œCivilian daily lifeâ€ (æ°‘é–“å¤§å°äº‹).

The ever-changing nature of this pandemic provides opportunities for suspicious messages to exploit the worry, fear, and panic that we all have. False information, information manipulation, and sometimes conspiracy theories. IORG is here with you to stay alert, stay calm, trust in science, and fact-check actively.

Full version of this Dokidoki Alert Weekly is available in Taiwanese Mandarin. Please visit https://iorg.tw/da/3 for more...
